content:
Sometimes I play with apply? and it closes the proof but I don't know which of the suggestions has "worked". The list in the VS Code pane appears alphabetical and is not very useful:

Screenshot 2025-02-12 at 22.05.07.png

Is there some way to introspect which of these has closed the goal?
Oops I meant to post this in #new members , apologies

I think it's lying to you -- or, I've noticed this before, but I think it always will show no goals afterwards (or at least I can't recall not seeing it do that, do you recall one?).

E.g., this example:

theorem foo : false := by
  apply?

also shows no goals, and clearly it hasn't succeeded.
If you do think it succeeded or want to see if one did, use exact?, and it only succeeds when it.. succeeds.
If it finds a solution, it will show a single suggestion, I think...
And I think the format is also slightly different
Oh ok that does make sense (I've seen that happen). Not a very intuitive UI interaction though. Would be nice to have this fixed somehow.
Dan Abramov has marked this topic as resolved.

Yes, currently when apply? gives a list of suggestions, but none immediately close the goal, it closes the goal with a sorry. To be honest I don't remember any reasonable rationale for this. I would merge a PR that changed this --- hopefully it's only a line or two that needs changing!
@Patrick Massot In another thread, you defended this feature. Can you say why you think it is good to have a tactic [edit: like apply?] succeed with a sorry?
(And to be clear, I mean for a human user.)
(Sorry, I tried to move a conversation here but failed a bit. the other conversation starts here: #Machine Learning for Theorem Proving > DeepSeek-Prover V2 @ ðŸ’¬)
Eric answered that question in the other thread.
